summary: This document is an email chain from May 2020 between the FBI NY CART (Computer Analysis and Response Team) and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) regarding the processing and transfer of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties. It details challenges in handling terabytes of data from numerous devices, coordinating the transfer into a usable format for discovery, and establishing a timeline for completion.

persons.name: FBI NY CART Coordinator Senior Examiner
persons.context: The primary FBI point of contact coordinating the extraction, processing, and transfer of digital evidence seized from Epstein's properties. They are managing terabytes of data from multiple devices.

events.title: Evidence Listing Provided
events.description: The FBI NY CART Coordinator sends a listing of all evidence gathered in NY from Epstein searches to the U.S. Attorney's Office, detailing devices and data sizes.
personsInvolved: FBI NY CART Coordinator Senior Examiner

events.title: Epstein Property Searches (NY & USVI)
events.description: Search warrants were executed at Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands, resulting in the seizure of numerous digital devices.

events.title: Epstein Arrest and Personal Device Seizure
events.description: Devices were seized from Epstein's person upon his arrest.

locations: The Island (likely referring to Epstein's private island)
keyFacts: The FBI was processing terabytes of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's New York and U.S. Virgin Islands properties, including phones, tablets, laptops, desktop computers, servers, DVRs, cameras, and loose media.

Significant challenges existed in transferring the data into a format usable by the U.S. Attorney's Office for discovery and taint review, specifically for loading into the Relativity e-discovery platform.
Specific devices mentioned as not yet transferred included 2 Macs, a DVR, an iPhone, and an iPad from the New York seizure.
The email chain reveals internal coordination issues and delays, partly due to the COVID-19 pandemic reducing FBI office presence to one day a week.

A key problem identified was that previously transferred data (over 1.1 million documents) lacked proper linking between emails and attachments, making review and future production to defense counsel difficult.
